text: Has anyone ever experimented with transforming podcast episodes into blog posts? We have two very successful podcasts where thought-leaders in the HR space discuss topics brought up by our audience. We're wondering if, translated into interview-style blog posts, they could become a good source of backlinks and maybe generate some PR opportunities. BUT it would be quite a lot of work for our small team, so we're evaluating pros and cons...

text:
Good input here! I'm seeing 3 different potential approaches here, which really could all work together:
1. Lifecycle stage > nurture flows > content --> Distribution = automated emails from marketing
2. Lifecycle stage > topic cluster > content (topic clusters would play very nicely with nurture flows) --> Distribution = search + automated emails from marketing
3. Lifecycle stage > content > battlecards that cluster content around topic or event sales play --> Distribution = sales folks 
I love the idea of battlecards as an approach to distro. So rather than try to surface individual content assets, you surface a "play" almost: "running into this objection?" "account using this integration?"  Here's the content for you!

Tying these all together would be pretty powerful!

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

Lifecycle stage > topic cluster > content (topic clusters would play very nicely with nurture flows) --> Distribution = search + automated emails from marketing
Lifecycle stage > content > battlecards that cluster content around topic or event sales play --> Distribution = sales folks

I love the idea of battlecards as an approach to distro. So rather than try to surface individual content assets, you surface a "play" almost: "running into this objection?" "account using this integration?"  Here's the content for you!

Tying these all together would be pretty powerful!

text:
Hi <@U037SBG1W3B>, a bit of a side thought, but if you’re planning to eventually launch a blog later this year, I highly recommend always publishing the content on your blog first and then importing it into Medium – explained here: <https://help.medium.com/hc/en-us/articles/214550207-Importing-a-post-to-Medium>

This way, you’ll make sure the canonical URL points to your site, and the content will still be there for readers on Medium :)

text: Has anyone helped write their company style guide, or done this as a consultant? I'm helping a company write their copy style guide, and am working on the questionnaire to provide them before I start. Trying to think of some other questions to put on there besides the obvious, like "how would you describe your brand to a friend?"

elements.text: Has anyone helped write their company style guide, or done this as a consultant? I'm helping a company write their copy style guide, and am working on the questionnaire to provide them before I start. Trying to think of some other questions to put on there besides the obvious, like "how would you describe your brand to a friend?"

text: Yes! I think it's important to understand their audiences - both primary and secondary - and what those audiences are like, both in terms of their brand (what do they need to think/know about their brand) and independently (what do they generally care about). This has been important in the past for me in figuring out tone - for example, a company selling products that affect people's lives (like a health product, or something for law enforcement) should probably have not have a glib or sassy tone because of how it could be perceived by both buyers and media covering the company.

elements.text: Yes! text:
Maybe look at just publishing the content on LinkedIn then instead of starting a Medium blog--esp if you're going to shut it down?

I"ve done a lot of personal stuff on Medium and the stuff you gain there (fans, likes etc) won't really carry over

At least on LI your audience will stay with you, and you can reach them quickly. (Unless you feel like your target audience is on Medium)

text: As Dana said, you should also look at their audiences/personas, if they don’t have any that’s something you need to develop or ask marketing to develop, through questionnaires, interviews etc. In your style guide you should include the brand values, and favoured/banned words, tone of voice, and examples of good and bad copy in terms of the brand and its needs.

elements.text: As Dana said, you should also look at their audiences/personas, if they don’t have any that’s something you need to develop or ask marketing to develop, through questionnaires, interviews etc. In your style guide you should include the brand values, and favoured/banned words, tone of voice, and examples of good and bad copy in terms of the brand and its needs.

text: I’ve done this in previous in-house roles, and helped with some barebones style guides for early startup clients. In addition to the persona callouts, some general questions might be “if your brand had a celebrity spokesperson, who would it be” and “does your CEO/founder/any of your company leaders embody a brand voice?” This last one is a little tricky to ask in a survey, but in my experience, it can be helpful to tease out if any individual in a company has a lot of influence over the brand voice. Sometimes a particularly charismatic founder/CEO basically functions as the brand voice, for better or worse, and it’s useful to know if that’s the case.

elements.text: I’ve done this in previous in-house roles, and helped with some barebones style guides for early startup clients. Sometimes a particularly charismatic founder/CEO basically functions as the brand voice, for better or worse, and it’s useful to know if that’s the case.

text: Hi Lexi. I've been working on building a website in Webflow for my previous employer. I think it is excellent and can be used in house (I built a ‘free-hand’ replica of or old WordPress site with no real previous web development experience). That said, it cost a lot of my time and spread me thin. I'd be happy to get on a call if you want.
